data.title: Settings: left hand side of folder settings should respect settings in that folder
data.body:
Refs: #31448

1. MR workspace, open settings for a folder
2. Chagne font size to 15, notice how only the right hand side applies the font change, the left hand side stays with the workspace setting

Left hand side should also apply the setting change so the user can immediatly see the affect of the change and not be confused.

![screen shot 2017-07-27 at 15 06 02](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926584/28671495-2d2d2b3c-72dd-11e7-9839-c7c1395fcdac.png)

data.title: Token color customisations not applied live
data.body:
Testing #31360

1. Open file with some variables defined.
2. Add 
`"editor.tokenColorCustomizations": {
		"variables": "#00f000"
}`
No live editor update is happening, although when closing and opening again, css colors are applied.

Works for `comments` and `keywords` color customisations.

data.title: Javascript syntax highlighting breaks on object literal with "<" in value
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e) - OS Version: macOS 10.12.5 Steps to Reproduce: ```javascript const foo = { '\n': '
' // this is the problematic line } function bar (text) { return String(text).replace(/[\n]/g, s => foo[s]) } ``` 1. Put the following code in a new file and make sure the language mode is set to JavaScript 2. Note that the syntax coloring breaks (function keyword has the same color as the function name). If the indicated line is removed, it works. Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Use comments on top of settings file to explain complex relationship between different settings
data.body:
Refs: #31448

1. Notice how there are comments on the first line of the user settings
2. There are no comments in folder or workspace settings

I suggest to add a one line comment to better explain the complex relationship between each of the settings.
Also in the folder settings you could specify that only some settings are supported and that their list can be seen on the left.

data.title: Settings: wording feedback
data.body:
Refs: #31448

"Place your folder settings here to overwrite those from the Workspace Settings". I would prefer
"Place your ${nameOfFolder} folder settings here to overwrite Workspace Settings"

"This setting cannot be currently applied because it does not support the folder resource scope. Changing it might impact other workspaces."

I would prefer 
"This setting cannot be currently applied because it does not support the folder resource scope. Changing it will have impact when {nameOfFolder} is opened outside of a workspaces."



![screen shot 2017-07-27 at 14 52 57](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926584/28670967-51162b5e-72db-11e7-9695-d279693c5ba5.png)

data.title: Duplicate edit actions in settings
data.body:
Refs: #31448

1. Hover over the edit action in the settings margin
2. Notice double hover

Also sometimes there are multiple edit actions in the margin, even though there should always be exactly one.

![screen shot 2017-07-27 at 14 49 24](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926584/28670880-f190b9d8-72da-11e7-82b8-7d6999bcc35e.png)

data.title: Bogous message when reordering workspace folders
data.body: testing #31396 * have a workspace with three folders * open workspace settings * swap the second and first path in the folders-section * 🐛 a popup tells me that our "extension system" needs to restart For once I doubt that is correct because only 0-1, 1-N transitions require a restart. Then I believe "extension system" isn't good wording. Let's just say the window needs to be reloaded (and obviously only when actually required to do so)

data.body: testing #31396 * have a workspace with three folders a, b, and c * open settings editor and edit settings for folder b * in the explorer remove folder b from the workspace * 🐛 the settings editor doesn't update, the drop down does...

data.title: Make PowerShell a first class citizen of VS Code
data.body:
VS Code is a powerful and loved editor by many, especially web developers. The open source nature, the extensions, the cross platform functionality, multiple language support and many other features make it a real power tool.

As a professional PowerShell developer and novice Java developer I can say that at the moment the editor is not ready for production, when writing `PowerShell` code. It feels like @daviwil  and @rkeithhill are the only ones helping out on the PowerShell part. With so many tickets it feels like they could use some extra help. Hence, this ticket.

Given that `PowerShell` is Microsofts number one scripting language, it would be great if more people could help out. I've taken the opportunity to list the most important issue of making the editor a succes below.

# Show stoppers:

1. Enable PSReadline support in the integrated console (syntax highlighting, keyboard navigation) (PowerShell/vscode-powershell#535)
   See IntelliSense in debug mode is behaving strange (PowerShell/vscode-powershell#948)
2. Copying code with a here string is incorrect (PowerShell/vscode-powershell#961)
    See: Language-aware folding (PowerShell/vscode-powershell#3422)

# Nice to haves

1. Debugger issues (PowerShell/vscode-powershell#956, PowerShell/vscode-powershell#985, PowerShell/vscode-powershell#987, PowerShell/vscode-powershell#1004)
2. 'Go to Definition' not opening the correct file (PowerShell/vscode-powershell#946)

Thank you for giving `PowerShell` a bit more TLC.

data.title: slightly inconsistent behaviour of asRelativePath and getWorkspaceFolder
data.body:
Testing #31369:

Assume a folder "test" with a single file "hello.js".

- Open the folder "test" in VS Code. This is the "single folder" case.
- Add another folder. This becomes the "multi folder" case.

Dependent on these cases `getWorkspaceFolder` and `asRelativePath` return these values:

API                              | single folder  | multi folder |
---------------------| ------------- | ------------- |
getWorkspaceFolder| test                     | test              |
asRelativePath          | hello.js              | test/hello.js  |

The problem: `getWorkspaceFolder` returns the same value, but `asRelativePath` returns different values.
If you use both functions in your code you'll probably need an additional check for `workspaceFolders.length > 1` to really understand what is going on.
(I was running into this problem already: #31523)

After discussion with @jrieken we came to the conclusion that we should keep the current behaviour of   `asRelativePath` (since it is convenient if you just need a short but unique path) but introduce an additional boolean argument that allows to get a more stable/robust behaviour: e.g. a value of true returns the path with a prepended folder name, and a value of false omits the folder name.

data.title: Expose keyup/keydown events to extensions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14
- OS Version: Any

It would be useful if an extension could hook into keydown/keyup events when _any_ key is pressed, not just when a keybind matches. So to have an event that is sent every time a key is pressed or released.

We have a plugin that attempts to detect how much the user is typing in any given language and it would be much more accurate to use keyup events instead of `onDidChangeTextDocument`, where you have problems with copy & pasting, editing of ranges and that sort.

data.title: Issue with closing brakets
data.body:
Hi guys!

- VSCode Version:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6302961/28665498-1aa13d96-72c4-11e7-89c1-0802e993987a.png)


- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

For some reason, some times, the powershell functions I write cannot be collapsed. In the GIF here under you that the small "+" in front of the function Manage-PowerPlan doesn't appears.

Sometimes adding more spaces between the function body and the command based help solves the issue, but it doesn't fix the issue at 100% of the time. I haven't found a logic on 'why it occurs', it seems to be random.

see here the recorded issue:


![closing brakets](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6302961/28665401-d5c2214a-72c3-11e7-9f52-93cf271a9c77.gif)

Cheers




1. copy code from gist--> https://gist.github.com/Stephanevg/5e345eb976da1eb276384b694fe8e5cd
2. Try to open close the function brakets



<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: No

data.title: 'End' key does not work in large file
data.body:
Testing #30243.

1. Generate file as in #31545.
2. Click on the first line somewhere to see a cursor, press 'End' key on the keyboard.

Expectation: navigating to the end of the line.
Ctrl+End does not navigate to the end of the document also.

data.title: Move focus to editor when scrolling with mouse wheel
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
tslint|eg2|0.17.0
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
debugger-for-chrome|msj|3.1.6
tsimporter|pmn|1.2.14
vscode-icons|rob|7.11.0
cordova-tools|vsm|1.2.7



---

Steps to Reproduce:

0. Open VSCode, with some previous tabs still open.
1. Hovering over any open tab's file, use the up/down mouse wheel to scroll around the file.
2. Press page up or page down, expecting the same file to page up or down. It doesn't, because the screen was not given focus, so the Explorer window pages up and down through the files; please change this.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Finish editing of CLI specified file should end --wait
data.body:
testing #30717:

I would expect that the "--wait" ends when the file specified as a CLI argument is closed in the editor. The current model of when "--wait" ends appears to me less intuitive.

In the following cases "--wait" did not end (but I was expecting that it would end):
- launch "code --wait foo.txt" and open a second file "abc.txt" in the same window. Close the editor with "foo.txt". Now I would expect the "--wait" to end but VS Code to stay open.
- launch "code --wait foo.txt" and load a folder in the same window. Now foo.txt is definitively not open any more but  "--wait" does not return.

data.title: Change all occurrences in a single 100MB line leads to a crash when autosave on

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Testing #30243.

32-bit Windows

0. Enable autosave. 
1. Open 100MB file generated by Dummy File Creator (non-random content). I got single line generated.
2. Type 'sd' in several places on the same line.
3. Do an edit via 'Change all occurrences' from the context menu.
Observe crash.

Should we disable triggering autosave for large files?

data.title: Reveal debug configuration when pressing edit
data.body:
testing #31396

Unsure if I have filed this already before

* open the vscode workspace which has ~15 launch configs
* select one to launch, notice you want to reconfigure it
* press the gear icon
* you are lost, the file is large, and the part which defines the currently selected configuration isn't revealed (but the last I have edited)

data.title: 200 MB file opens but crashes after several edits
data.body:
Testing #30243

OS: Windows 32bit
Extensions: none
Hardware configuration: 8 GB RAM (7.82 usable), x64

1. Generate 200MB non-random content file using Dummy File Creator (46 lines of spaces)
2.  Open it
3. Do single edit
Observe crash. 

Seems like 300MB limit for 32bit is very rough and is probably very hardware specific. Maybe we should have more variables to define limit size?

This is how memory looks when editor opened untouched:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2239563/28664517-0eda0fd6-72c1-11e7-9df8-46ff5f3125ef.png)

Opening and editing for 100MB works fine (although with lags obviously).

_Dummy File Creator: http://www.mynikko.com/dummy/_

data.title: Debug control dropdown doesn't show workspace folder
data.body: testing #31396 While the launch control shows the workspace folder, like `Foo Config (Bar Workspace)`, the debug controller just shows `Foo Config`. That might be a problem when I have multiple with the same name running.

Open loaded script quick open command only takes first session into account

data.body:
Refs: #31327

1. Start two debug sessions
2. Quick open > open scripts
3. Notice that the quick open entries only show results for the first session

I would expect that the quick open and the viewlet view are alligned, so in quick open I would expect that multiple groups are used. Each group for a session (not sure if this is possible from an extension though). If not, then just showing them together is better than just showing one.

data.title: Jobber.exe makes trouble with virus scanner F-Secure
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.3.9600
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
project-manager|ale|0.18.1
githistory|don|0.2.2
gitlens|eam|4.3.2
rest-client|hum|0.14.6



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.   I updated VScode to the current version
2.   I restarted the app for the changes take effect and get the following F-Secure warning: 
PotentiallyUnwanted:W32/App.0750e025c8!Online, 
<Users>\<me>\.vscode\extensions\eamodio.gitlens-4.3.2\node_modules\spawn-rx\vendor\jobber\Jobber.exe

3. I disabled scanning for this file (created exception)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

Sorry, didn't check without extensions (gitlens), since I'm  working with git.
I suppose the file properties and/or  the lack of digital signature  might be a source of this trouble. 
Try code signing it.
